title: Bloomberg Markets 12/12/2025
description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests: BitGo Co-Founder and CEO Mike Belshe, Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow, Keith Naughton, Dave Lee and Poonam Goyal.

title: Australian Lithium Miner Ioneer Eyes Bid for Rio‚Äôs US Boron Unit
description: Australian mining firm Ioneer Ltd. is interested in bidding on a bundle of Rio Tinto Group‚Äôs US assets that produce boron, a critical mineral used in fertilizer, according to its top executive.
fullText: MarketsBy Jacob LorincSaveAustralian mining firm Ioneer Ltd. is interested in bidding on a bundle of Rio Tinto Group‚Äôs US assets that produce boron, a critical mineral used in fertilizer, according to its top executive.Chief Executive Officer Bernard Rowe said he sees an opportunity to consolidate Ioneer‚Äôs boron-and-lithium project in Nevada with Rio‚Äôs boron operations in California that it‚Äôs seeking to sell. Bloomberg reported in late November on Rio‚Äôs plans to soon start a sales process to divest the assets.

title: The Best-Performing ETF of All Time Is on a 49,310% Run
description: How could this possibly be the case?

title: Quebec‚Äôs Troilus Mining Set to Get Electricity for Gold Project
description: Troilus Mining Corp. landed a deal that could help supply the development-stage firm with the electricity needed to restart a Quebec gold mine, according to a document released by a provincial lawmaker.
fullText: IndustriesBy Mathieu DionSaveTroilus Mining Corp. landed a deal that could help supply the development-stage firm with the electricity needed to restart a Quebec gold mine, according to a document released by a provincial lawmaker.The Montreal-based company owns the Troilus mine in northern Quebec, which was operated by Inmet Mining Corp. from 1996 until the facility‚Äôs closing in 2010. Troilus Mining plans to restart the operation, but has been seeking affordable electricity to advance the project.

title: Wall Street Whiplash Hits Trend Chasers in Year of Endless Noise
description: All year, Wall Street has braced for something big to break.
fullText: MarketsBy Denitsa Tsekova and Ye XieSaveAll year, Wall Street has braced for something big to break.There have been AI bubble warnings day in, day out ‚Äî flaring up again this week after cautious signals from Oracle Corp. and Broadcom Inc. rattled faith in the trade‚Äôs staying power. That anxiety helped drag the Nasdaq 100 down as much as 2.3% on Friday, knocking some of the year‚Äôs biggest winners off recent highs.

title: Oracle Debt Trades Like Junk as Bond, CDS Spreads Flare
description: Oracle Corp.‚Äôs new investment-grade notes are now trading more like junk bonds, as delays on the completion dates for some data centers add to fears about profits from its artificial intelligence investments.
fullText: MarketsBy Caleb MutuaSaveOracle Corp.‚Äôs new investment-grade notes are now trading more like junk bonds, as delays on the completion dates for some data centers add to fears about profits from its artificial intelligence investments.Extending declines after quarterly earnings earlier this week, paper losses for investors that bought the $18 billion of high-grade notes that Oracle sold in September now totals about $1.35 billion, according to Bloomberg News analysis. The bonds were issued as the company ramps up spending on AI projects.

title: "Real Yield" Debate on Credit: Own or Not Own?
description: On "Bloomberg Real Yield", Alexander Wolf, global head of macro and fixed income strategy at J.P. Morgan Private Bank, and Mike Contopoulos, deputy chief investment officer at Richard Bernstein Advisors, talks with Matt Miller about the Fed's rate decision this week, the next Fed chair and corporate credit. Analysts say that there‚Äôs plenty to worry about when it comes to credit, from AI oversupply and private market distress to asset-backed blowups and runaway rates.

title: Apollo Awards $23.5 Million of Bonuses to Finance, Legal Chiefs
description: Apollo Global Management Inc. is giving its finance chief and top lawyer retention bonuses totaling $23.5 million.
fullText: IndustriesBy Laura BenitezSaveApollo Global Management Inc. is giving its finance chief and top lawyer retention bonuses totaling $23.5 million.Chief Financial Officer Martin Kelly and Chief Legal Officer Whitney Chatterjee will receive restricted share units worth $10 million and $13.5 million, respectively, according to a regulatory filing Friday. The awards will be granted Dec. 18.

title: Stocks Slide as Tech Selloff Deepens | Closing Bell
description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Katie Greifeld, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.

title: Airline Azul Wins US Court Approval of Restructuring Plan
description: Brazilian airline Azul SA won US court permission to exit bankruptcy and implement a creditor-backed restructuring that trims debt and lines up new investment from United Airlines Holdings Inc. and American Airlines Group Inc.
fullText: IndustriesTransportationBy Jonathan RandlesSaveBrazilian airline Azul SA won US court permission to exit bankruptcy and implement a creditor-backed restructuring that trims debt and lines up new investment from United Airlines Holdings Inc. and American Airlines Group Inc. Judge Sean Lane said during a court hearing late Friday in New York that he‚Äôd approve the airline‚Äôs plan to reorganize, clearing Azul‚Äôs path to leave Chapter 11 early next year. The deal cuts more than $2.6 billion in debt and aircraft lease obligations and raises as much as $950 million in new equity investments, according to court papers.

title: Paramount‚Äôs $54 Billion Debt Plays a Starring Role in Warner Bid
description: Even if Paramount Skydance Corp. manages to take over Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. against the company‚Äôs will, it faces another high hurdle: coping with the colossal $54 billion of debt it‚Äôs planning to take on.
fullText: IndustriesEntertainmentBy Claire Ruckin and Caleb MutuaSaveEven if Paramount Skydance Corp. manages to take over Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. against the company‚Äôs will, it faces another high hurdle: coping with the colossal $54 billion of debt it‚Äôs planning to take on.Paramount has a temporary financing package in place for the combined company, but it hasn‚Äôt locked in a maximum rate on more permanent borrowings for the transaction. The result could be the M&A world‚Äôs version of a big-budget Hollywood fiasco, with Paramount‚Äôs expenses spiraling beyond what it planned if debt markets sour and funding costs surge.

title: Overall Spreads Remain Tight Even As Oracle Debt Risk Jumps
description: On "Bloomberg Real Yield", Maureen O'Connor, global head of high-grade debt syndicate at Wells Fargo Corporate & Investment Bank, and Amanda Lynam, head of macro credit research at BlackRock, talks with Matt Miller about credit spreads, issuance and risks tied to the boom in AI growth. There‚Äôs a frenzy of development going on to support the AI revolution, and with it an insatiable demand for debt to fund it. Some estimate the overall infrastructure roll-out cost could reach $10 trillion, and with so many lenders lining up to throw cash at the assets, the fear is a bubble is building.

title: Affordability a 2026 Concern: Amalgamated CEO
description: Priscilla Sims Brown, Amalgamated Bank CEO, says most people agree affordability is a major concern. She tells Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on ‚ÄúThe Close‚Äù that the bank is deeply engaged in its Commercial Property Assessed Clean Energy program and that 40% of its lending is climate related.

title: Serhant on NY Real Estate, New Season of "Owning Manhattan"
description: Ryan Serhant, SERHANT CEO, says New York City doesn‚Äôt have enough rental supply to meet demand. He tells Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on ‚ÄúThe Close‚Äù that prices are high not because of market forces but because of policy.

title: Thoma Looks to Create $12 Billion Shipping Tech Firm With Merger
description: Thoma Bravo is in talks to merge its shipping software firm Auctane Inc., formerly known as Stamps.com, with third-party logistics provider WWEX Group to form a business that could be worth as much as $12 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
fullText: MarketsBy Carmen Arroyo and Ryan GouldSaveThoma Bravo is in talks to merge its shipping software firm Auctane Inc., formerly known as Stamps.com, with third-party logistics provider WWEX Group to form a business that could be worth as much as $12 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter.The private equity firm is set to inject about $500 million of new equity into the combined company under the proposal, which would cut costs and leverage for both units, said the people, who asked not to be identified discussing confidential information. Talks are ongoing and a deal may not materialize, they said.

title: Noem Contempt Hearing on Venezuelan Removals Halted by Court
description: A federal appeals court temporarily blocked a judge from holding a hearing on whether Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem and others were in contempt of court by deporting two planeloads of alleged Venezuelan gang members.
fullText: PoliticsBy David Voreacos and Zoe TillmanSaveA federal appeals court temporarily blocked a judge from holding a hearing on whether Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem and others were in contempt of court by deporting two planeloads of alleged Venezuelan gang members. In a one-page unsigned order late Friday, a panel of judges in Washington halted the hearing from going forward Dec. 15 and 16 after the Trump administration argued that US District Judge James Boasberg has no constitutional authority to proceed and compel testimony from current and former government attorneys. The panel said it‚Äôs still reviewing the case and that its order should not be construed as a decision on the merits of the dispute.

title: Intel Nears $1.6 Billion Deal for AI Chip Startup SambaNova
description: Intel Corp. is in advanced talks to acquire artificial intelligence chip startup SambaNova Systems Inc. for about $1.6 billion including debt, according to people familiar with the matter.
fullText: TechnologyAIBy Ryan Gould, Liana Baker, and Ian KingSaveIntel Corp. is in advanced talks to acquire artificial intelligence chip startup SambaNova Systems Inc. for about $1.6 billion including debt, according to people familiar with the matter.A deal for Palo Alto, California-based SambaNova could come together as soon as next month, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the information is confidential.

title: OpenTable CEO on 2026 Dining Trends
description: Debby Soo, OpenTable CEO, says consumers continue to prioritize dining out and the overall restaurant experience. She speaks with Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on ‚ÄúThe Close.‚Äù

title: The Fed‚Äôs Next Chair Faces AI Uncertainty, Political Heat and Credit Risks
description: The Federal Reserve has just cut rates by 25 basis points into an economy it still expects to grow faster next year, raising questions about why it eased and how much further it can go. Former Council of Economic Advisers chair Glenn Hubbard discusses the decision, the neutral rate and why he doesn‚Äôt see much more room for rate cuts going into 2026.

title: TPG Takes $600 Million Hit on ‚ÄòEyebrow Queen‚Äô Cosmetics Bet
description: TPG Inc. exited most of its stake in Anastasia Beverly Hills as part of a debt restructuring, largely wiping out the private equity firm‚Äôs $600 million investment in the cosmetics company, according to people familiar with the matter.
fullText: MarketsBy Laura Benitez and Allison McNeelySaveTPG Inc. exited most of its stake in Anastasia Beverly Hills as part of a debt restructuring, largely wiping out the private equity firm‚Äôs $600 million investment in the cosmetics company, according to people familiar with the matter. TPG purchased about 38% of the beauty company from its founders in 2018, in a deal that was financed with a combination of debt taken on by Anastasia and preferred shares bought by TPG.

title: Cambodia, Thai Clashes Continue After Trump‚Äôs Ceasefire Claim
description: Thailand said it will continue military actions against Cambodia to eliminate ‚Äúharm and threats,‚Äù stepping up rhetoric even after US President Donald Trump claimed to have brokered a new ceasefire.
fullText: WorldBy Patpicha TanakasempipatSaveThailand said it will continue military actions against Cambodia to eliminate ‚Äúharm and threats,‚Äù stepping up rhetoric even after US President Donald Trump claimed to have brokered a new ceasefire. Fighting entered its seventh day across the two countries‚Äô disputed border. Thailand said Cambodia has been attacking and firing rockets into civilian areas since Friday night and into Saturday morning, prompting Thailand to respond by attacking military targets.

title: How Long Does It Take to Merge a PR into VSCode?
description: Published @Yesterday
fullText:
I got my first open source contribution today üôå. This morning, my 4-line PR to vscode was finally merged into main.

The bug I found/fixed is very small. I‚Äôm sure 99.99% of VSCode users have never used the Delete Duplicate Lines command utility. I used this utility frequently during one of my past internships and seeing the issue everyday irritated me enough to make a PR.

I forgot about the PR until today when I received an approval notification from GitHub triggered. The PR was created on November 27, 2024, so it took 380 days to get reviewed and merged. This made me wonder how long it usually takes a PR to get merged into popular open source projects.

I used the VSCode repository as a case study. I‚Äôm going to guess there are 2 categories of people who contribute

GitHub has a GraphQL endpoint that can fetch information about PRs to public repos. I asked ChatGPT to write a script to fetch the most recent 10_000 PRs merged. In practice, I couldn‚Äôt do this because the GraphQL API only allows order by UPDATED_AT or CREATED_AT (according to ChatGPT). I verified manually with the API.

I used UPDATED_AT as a proxy for MERGED_AT since I filter for states: MERGED in the query. The full script can be found at the end of the blog.

title: Writing a Type-Safe Linux Perf Interface in Zig
description: I'm building a benchmarking tool for Zig and needed CPU counters. This is how I wrapped Linux's `perf_event_open` to be type-safe with comptime.
fullText:
I am currently building a hobby project:
pyk/bench, a microbenchmarking library for Zig.
My goal is to make it fast and accurate. To measure performance properly,
looking at wall clock time is not enough. I need to know what the CPU is
actually doing.

I want to measure CPU cycles, instruction counts and cache misses. On Linux the
kernel provides a system call for this named
perf_event_open.
It is very powerful but the API is raw and not easy to use safely.

The perf_event_open system call creates a file descriptor that allows
measuring performance information. You fill out a perf_event_attr struct with
the config you want, such as PERF_COUNT_HW_CPU_CYCLES or
PERF_COUNT_HW_INSTRUCTIONS, and the kernel gives you back a file descriptor.

You can read from this file descriptor to get the counts. The format of the data
you read depends on how you opened it.

You can also group events. This is important because it lets you measure
multiple things at once with a single read call. One event acts as the ‚Äúgroup
leader‚Äù and others are ‚Äúsiblings‚Äù. When you read from the leader, you get a
binary layout containing values for all events in the group.

The layout looks roughly like this in C:

This is dynamic. The size of the struct changes based on how many events you
have. In Zig I want something static and type-safe.

My first attempt was brittle. I hardcoded a struct with the fields I thought I
would need.

This works but it is dangerous. The Measurements struct is hardcoded.

If I change the initialization logic to add ‚Äúbranch misses‚Äù, I have to remember
to update Measurements, update the ids array size and update the read
function manually. The compiler cannot help me here.

If I access ids[2] but only initialized 2 events, I crash or get garbage data.

Zig allows running code at compile time to generate types. I can use this to
generate a struct that exactly matches the events I request.

I defined an Event enum for the things I want to measure.

Then I wrote a function that takes a slice of these events and returns a new
type.

This function creates a struct with fields named after the enum tags. If I pass
&.{ .cpu_cycles, .instructions }, it generates:

Now I can create a generic Group type that uses this.

The usage is cleaner and safer.

If I try to access a field I did not request, the compiler stops me.

Here is how the full version looks like:

To implement this I needed to get the ID of the event from the file descriptor.
The kernel documentation says to use ioctl with PERF_EVENT_IOC_ID.

I checked std.os.linux in the Zig standard library and it was missing.

So I opened a pull request to add it. It is just a one line change.

You can see the PR here:
https://codeberg.org/ziglang/zig/pulls/30162.
I am not sure if it will be accepted but it felt good to fix a missing piece in
the tool I use.

title: Browser4 ‚Äì an open-source browser engine for agents and concurrency
description: Browser4: a lightning-fast, coroutine-safe browser for your AI. - platonai/Browser4
fullText:

title: Google and Apple roll out emergency security updates after zero-day attacks
description: Apple released patches for all of its flagship devices to fix security flaws under attack. Google also updated Chrome to remediate one vulnerability exploited in the attacks.
fullText:
Apple and Google have released several software updates to protect against a hacking campaign targeting an unknown number of their users.

On Wednesday, Google released patches for a handful of security bugs in its Chrome browser, noting that one of the bugs was being actively exploited by hackers before the company had time to patch it.

Unusually for Google, the company provided no further details at the time.

But on Friday, Google updated the page to say that the bug was discovered by Apple‚Äôs security engineering team and Google‚Äôs Threat Analysis Group, whose security researchers primarily track government hackers and mercenary spyware makers, indicating that the hacking campaign may have been orchestrated by government-backed hackers.

At the same time, Apple released security updates for its flagship products, including iPhones, iPads, Macs, Vision Pro, Apple TV, Apple Watches, and its Safari browser.

According to the security advisory for iPhones and iPads, Apple patched two bugs and the company said it was aware ‚Äúthat this issue may have been exploited in an extremely sophisticated attack against specific targeted individuals‚Äù running devices prior to iOS 26.

That language is Apple‚Äôs typical way of saying that it knows some of its customers and users were targeted by hackers exploiting zero-days, meaning flaws that at the time of exploitation are unknown to the software makers. Often, these are cases where government hackers used hacking tools and spyware made by companies such as NSO Group or Paragon Solutions to target journalists, dissidents, and human rights activists.

Apple and Google did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

title: Democratic states sue Trump administration over new $100k fee for H-1B visas
description: A coalition of blue states is suing the Trump administration over its fee of $100,000 for H-1B Visas, several Democratic attorneys general announced on Friday.
fullText:
A coalition of blue states is suing the Trump administration over its fee of $100,000 for H-1B Visas, several Democratic attorneys general announced on Friday.

The Trump administration announced in September that it would be implementing the fee for H-1B visas, citing that the program for the visas is overused. California Attorney General Rob Bonta, joined by Massachusetts Attorney General Andrea Joy Campbell and New York Attorney General Letitia James and others, is leading the suit.

H-1B visas allow foreign professionals to seek work in professions that are considered to be more specialized. Applicants must hold a bachelor‚Äôs degree or a similar equivalent to be eligible for the visa.

The liberal attorneys general allege that new policy and fee, which is implemented by the Department of Homeland Security, is out of bounds of what is authorized by Congress for the program.

‚ÄúCongress has refined this program, setting caps, establishing fees, enhancing enforcement and strengthening protections, but what Congress has never done is authorize a president to impose a six-figure surcharge designed to dismantle the program entirely,‚Äù Bonta said at a press conference on Friday.

Bonta said the visa fee will create financial burdens on state and private employers, creating a barrier to filling job vacancies.

He also underscored just how many employees in the United States rely on the H-1B visa program, citing the thousands of health care professionals, educators and researchers, among other occupations, that use the program. Bonta claimed nearly 30,000 educators nationwide hold an H-1B visa, and 17,000 H-1B visa holders last year were health care professionals.

Bonta said during the press conference the state of California has filed 49 lawsuits against the Trump administration since they took office in January.

‚ÄúThe bottom line is, no presidential administration can rewrite immigration law,‚Äù Bonta said. ‚ÄúNo president can destabilize our schools, our hospitals and universities on a whim, and no president can ignore the co-equal branch of government, of Congress, ignore the Constitution or ignore the law.‚Äù

CNN has reached out to the Department of Homeland Security for comment on the lawsuit. The Justice Department declined to comment.

title: There is no data-generating distribution
description: Reflecting on teaching machine learning again. Again.
fullText:
Hi Ben, you might find this preprint of interest https://arxiv.org/abs/2407.17395 Perhaps you are making similar points.

It is curious that machine learning folks, who often like to say they are "data driven" pay little attention to the data at a conceptual level. I think the issue is that the data is taken to be _given_ (as you allude -- someone "gives you" a bunch of data). The word "data" derives from the latin word (dare) meaning to give. We would be better served to think of capta.... but collecting data is not considered as sexy as making complex models.

One argument (that simply is wrong) is that the existence of distributions is justified by the "law" of large numbers. It is not. For an argument regarding this, and an alternative (to distributions), you might find this other paper of interest. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0888613X24000355 It shows what you get when you don't assume the "law" of large numbers holds (i.e. that relative frequencies converge). That the result is something other folks had studied for some time is pretty interesting. That coherent upper previsions arise elsewhere in ML (in fairness, DRO and even in SVMs!) suggests they are not so weird after all....

A common viewpoint is that there is a set of all possible data out there (e.g., all images on the web). We collect a subset of these data and train our model. The main (and likely unreasonable) assumption is that the training subset is an iid sample (or uniformly sampled w/o replacement) from the set of all possible data. This assumption is the central ingredient in theoretical generalization bounds. While it's probably not perfectly reasonable, it does give us a framework for comparing models and algorithms, and aligns with common practices like hold-out validation. I think this is a useful model of the (training) data-generating distribution.

title: Marco Rubio: No more woke fonts
description: Marco Rubio has spoken‚Äîget out of here, Calibri!
fullText:
Marco Rubio here, with an important announcement: No more Calibri in official State Department communications! Get out of here with your ungarnished lines and provocatively naked terminals! The Biden administration may have shot the serif, switching from Times New Roman on the grounds that serif-less fonts such as Calibri are more accessible to readers with disabilities. That‚Äôs all over now.

 The State Department Action Request reads: ‚ÄúTo restore decorum and professionalism to the Department‚Äôs written work products and abolish yet another wasteful DEIA [Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility] program, the Department is returning to Times New Roman as its standard typeface.‚Äù

 Now you can read a sentence like ‚ÄúYes, the United States did just seize an oil tanker off the coast of Venezuela! Don‚Äôt worry about it,‚Äù and bask in the sense of absolute decorum that comes from seeing a little serif on all of the relevant letters.

Some further updates to our font preferences:

The Justice Department will be switching to Comic Sans because current fonts have a veneer of professionalism that feels out of place in communications written by Lindsey Halligan. Now all ‚Äúfundamental misstatements of law‚Äù (a judge‚Äôs words, not ours!) will be in a font where they will feel more at home.

The Department of Transportation is switching to Goudy Old Style to fix everyone‚Äôs biggest problem with air travel: pajamasThe fonts aren‚Äôt square enough!

It will also be phasing out Clearview on road signs, on the grounds that this typeface is entirely too legible. Legibility is DEIA at work. People should struggle to read. This is also why we are dismantling the Department of Education.

Also, NASA is going to be using the logo font, where the A‚Äôs all look like upside-down V‚Äôs, for all communications, just to create an extra challenge for its already-overworked scientists. AAAAAA!

The Treasury Department will be switching to Akkadian cuneiform in honor of Ea-Nasir, our Businessman of the Month! The Trump administration shares his values. We are phasing out the penny, but one thing we‚Äôre not phasing out? Quality copper! Just buy some! And if you want to complain about it, write to us in Akkadian cuneiform!

The FBI is communicating entirely in Wingdings; this is because Kash Patel clicked something by mistake and is not actually policy.

The Department of Homeland Security is getting rid of Futura and bringing back our medieval gothic blackletter favorites with a switch to Fraktur. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean, you‚Äôre bringing our medieval fonts back? What medieval fonts? What country do you think this is?‚Äù Germany, right? 1930s, right? If not, we‚Äôre going to be very embarrassed. In general, when selecting a font or making any other kind of design choice, think, Would this look out of place on a Leni Riefenstahl film poster?

The Health and Human Services Department is switching entirely to Papyrus. Finally, a font as embarrassing and unscientific as our ideas. When you read a press release saying that vaccinations are no longer recommended, now it‚Äôll be in a font that looks like it‚Äôs advertising tropical-drink specials or chakra alignment.

The Department of Labor will switch to handwriting. Just to create more labor.

The Department of War will not be updating its fonts at this time. Instead, it will be switching from written to verbal communications. This isn‚Äôt because we are worried that some of our orders might not be legal. It‚Äôs‚Äîcall and we‚Äôll explain. Just call. Or you can probably reach Pete Hegseth on Signal.

title: Ozempic Turned a 1970s Hit into an Inescapable Jingle (2024)
description: The diabetes drug has become a phenomenon, and ‚ÄúOh, oh, oh, Ozempic!‚Äù ‚Äî a takeoff of the Pilot song ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù ‚Äî has played a big part in its story.
fullText:
In February 2023, David Paton, guitar case in hand, strode across the most famous pedestrian walkway in rock history and into London‚Äôs Abbey Road Studios.

Paton was no stranger to the rooms where the Beatles changed the course of popular music: His 1970s pop-rock band Pilot recorded two albums there. In his second life, as an in-demand studio and touring musician for the likes of Kate Bush and Elton John, he clocked numerous sessions with the prog-rock outfit the Alan Parsons Project, whose namesake produced Pilot‚Äôs signature hit, ‚ÄúMagic.‚Äù He even spent some time there with his boyhood hero, Paul McCartney, singing backup vocals on Wings‚Äô ‚ÄúMull of Kintyre.‚Äù

Paton had come to London to record a new version of ‚ÄúMagic.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt was a great thrill to be back at Abbey Road, singing my song,‚Äù he said in a recent video interview from his home studio in Edinburgh, an array of guitars displayed behind him. The track‚Äôs stair-step chorus ‚Äî ‚ÄúOh, oh, oh/it‚Äôs MAAA-gic‚Äù ‚Äî could test Paton‚Äôs vocal range even back in 1974, and again a year later, when the song became a worldwide hit, peaking at No. 5 on the Billboard Hot 100.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just about the enjoyment of life,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAbout waking up in the morning, you know? I was 22 when I wrote it.‚Äù Now he was 73, and unsure if he could still reach those high notes. But Paton took his place in front of the Abbey Road microphone and confidently sang that indelible hook, only with the word ‚Äúmagic‚Äù swapped out for something less ephemeral and more pharmaceutical: ‚ÄúOh, oh, oh, Ozempic.‚Äù

As television viewers are all too aware, that altered chorus from ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù serves as the advertising jingle for the Type 2 diabetes medication Ozempic. Since the product arrived in 2018, the bowdlerized version of ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù ‚Äî first rerecorded by work-for-hire musicians, and then re-rerecorded by Paton at Abbey Road ‚Äî has taken its place alongside such classics of the form as Subway‚Äôs ‚ÄúFive Dollar Foot Long‚Äù and McDonald‚Äôs ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Lovin‚Äô It‚Äù as marvels of marketing ingenuity.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an earworm all right,‚Äù said David Allan, a professor of marketing at Saint Joseph‚Äôs University and the author of ‚ÄúThis Note‚Äôs for You,‚Äù a book about music and advertising. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt get it out of your head.‚Äù

Those three seconds of AM-radio bliss ‚Äî ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a first, a third and a fifth note,‚Äù Paton modestly explained ‚Äî have played a pivotal role in the Ozempic story. Its parent company, Novo Nordisk, has now become Europe‚Äôs most valuable public company, with a market cap of nearly $570 billion.

Ozempic, of course, has become much more than a diabetes drug: Its ‚Äúoff label‚Äù use to treat obesity has sparked a ‚Äúweight-loss revolution,‚Äù as Oprah Winfrey called it in her March TV special dedicated to an emerging group of diabetes and anti-obesity medications. Buttressed by an ad spend of $120 million over just the first seven months of 2023, according to MediaRadar, Ozempic‚Äôs Q rating is such that the brand now stands in for an entire category of product, as Viagra does for erectile dysfunction drugs. On the March 30 episode of ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live,‚Äù the comedian Ramy Youssef appeared in a spoof commercial for ‚ÄúOzempic for Ramadan‚Äù that featured the familiar ‚ÄúOh, oh, oh‚Äù of ‚ÄúMagic.‚Äù

This Ozempic boom is due in no small part to the jingle, which helped turn a byzantine mash-up of syllables into a brand patients would request from doctors by name. Jeremy Shepler, who headed the Ozempic launch in the United States for Novo Nordisk, had previously enjoyed success deploying music in a commercial for a new-to-market nasal spray, and knew he wanted to find a song that worked both mnemonically and emotionally.

‚ÄúThe first song I came up with was by New Kids on the Block, the one that goes ‚ÄòOh oh oh oh oh‚Äô,‚Äù he sang, referring to ‚ÄúYou Got It (The Right Stuff).‚Äù ‚ÄúBut New Kids was a bit too young,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe average age of our patient was between 50 and 55. Then it came to me: ‚ÄòOh, oh, oh, it‚Äôs magic.‚Äô‚Äù

That snippet of a chorus not only seared the ‚ÄúO‚Äù in Ozempic into consumers‚Äô temporal lobes, but its cheerfulness sold the promise of the drug: to ‚Äúhelp people get back to a level of health when their life was bright and their future was optimistic,‚Äù said Jeff Rothstein, chief executive of CultHealth, the ad agency for Ozempic. Also, baby boomers exposed to the jingle would subconsciously hear the missing word ‚Äúmagic,‚Äù which, said Shepler, helped reinforce the drug‚Äôs transformative quality.

Novo licensed the song from Sony Music Publishing, and Rothstein hired a music production house to record the brand-specific version of ‚ÄúMagic.‚Äù When they tested a rough version of the commercial, ‚ÄúIt was the highest scoring ad we‚Äôd ever seen,‚Äù Shepler said.

As the spot first began airing in 2018 (direct-to-consumer pharmaceutical advertising is allowed only in the United States and New Zealand), Paton wasn‚Äôt even aware that ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù had been licensed for the advert. ‚ÄúI learned about it through Facebook,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúFans would write me, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm hearing ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù every 20 minutes on my TV‚Äô.‚Äù

Paton and Billy Lyall, his Pilot bandmate who died in 1989 at age 36, share a co-writing credit on ‚ÄúMagic,‚Äù and split the revenue generated by the composition with Sony Publishing. (Songs generate multiple income streams, some based on the performance or master recording, some based on the songwriting. In this case, since the original recording of ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù was not used by Novo Nordisk, Pilot‚Äôs record label, Warner Music Group, was not involved.)

As is common practice in the music industry, Sony was not obligated to receive permission from the songwriters to license the song. Not that Paton minded: Three music-industry executives, asked separately to assess the value of the Ozempic deal, said it was most likely worth seven figures to Paton. (Paton, Sony Music Publishing and Novo Nordisk all declined to discuss financial terms of the deal.)

The Ozempic commercial ‚Äúis another example of why classic, iconic music catalogs are great investments,‚Äù said Jon Singer, chairman of Spirit Music Group, a music publishing company with a repertoire that includes songs by the Who, Chicago, Toto and T. Rex.

‚ÄúMusic as an asset can have multiple lives,‚Äù added Billy Mann, a Grammy-nominated songwriter and longtime publishing executive. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a ‚Äòcomfort food‚Äô feeling of nostalgia that hit songs can trigger. They‚Äôre time machines.‚Äù

In the Spotify era, older songs have spiked in value, as consumers repeatedly press play on the songs of their youth. For artists, those fractions of a penny eventually add up, and that has helped create a gold rush for veteran acts looking to sell their music catalogs. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a finite number of songs that have proven to be iconic for 40 or 50 years,‚Äù said Bill Werde, the director of the Bandier music business program at Syracuse University and the author of the industry newsletter ‚ÄúFull Rate No Cap.‚Äù ‚ÄúThose songs have special value on the marketplace.‚Äù

Licensing a song for a commercial may be seen by some as antithetical to the countercultural spirit of rock ‚Äôn‚Äô roll. ‚ÄúThere have always been protectors of the flame who, when certain songs get used in certain moments, aggressively clutch their pearls,‚Äù Werde said. ‚ÄúBut there‚Äôs very little evidence that this has ever harmed any artist.‚Äù He pointed to the Beatles licensing their utopian ‚ÄúAll You Need Is Love‚Äù to Luvs diapers in 2007 as perhaps the most egregious example of an advertiser co-opting a song‚Äôs original meaning. ‚ÄúBut no one really cared. It was Ob-la-di. Life goes on.‚Äù

Simon Allaway, 52, an Ozempic user and Chicago-based computer programmer and musician, loves the ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù spot. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt help but sing along to it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a perfect fit with the product.‚Äù Another user wrote in a message-board post that whenever she injects herself, her father sings ‚ÄúOh, oh, oh, Ozempic.‚Äù

‚ÄúMagic‚Äù has been leased plenty of times before, for a Coca-Cola commercial ‚Äî ‚ÄúI actually sang ‚ÄòCoke, Coke, Coke, it‚Äôs Magic‚Äô back in the ‚Äô70s,‚Äù Paton recalled ‚Äî for the 2005 Disney film ‚ÄúHerbie: Fully Loaded‚Äù and as the musical bed for Flo Rida‚Äôs 2009 single, also called ‚ÄúMagic,‚Äù to name a few. ‚ÄúPeople always want to use the song in some way or the other,‚Äù Paton said.

Asked if he was bothered by his song‚Äôs association with what turned out to be a lightning-rod product, he smiled and shook his head. ‚ÄúI was delighted! I‚Äôm a songwriter. I want to sell my music. A lot of people don‚Äôt know the name Pilot, but they know the Ozempic song.‚Äù

For musicians, the success of the Ozempic commercial could be a harbinger of big checks to come. Pharmaceutical companies have seemingly unlimited budgets to promote their wares: according to the media analytics firm Guideline, pharma surpassed tech and auto in 2023 to become the second largest industry for ad spending, behind only consumer packaged goods.

Already, Lady Gaga is a spokesperson for Pfizer‚Äôs migraine medication Nurtec ODT; Cyndi Lauper lends her distinct Brooklyn accent to a commercial for Cosentyx, which treats plaque psoriasis; John Legend and Charlie Puth pitch Pfizer‚Äôs Covid vaccine and boosters. The Jackson 5‚Äôs ‚ÄúABC‚Äù propels ads for Trelegy (used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), while commercials for the heart drug Entresto are soundtracked by Sonny & Cher‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Beat Goes On.‚Äù

But those spots haven‚Äôt embedded themselves into pop culture the way ‚ÄúOh, oh, oh, Ozempic‚Äù has.

‚ÄúIn contemporary advertising, campaigns tend to have pretty short shelf lives,‚Äù CultHealth‚Äôs Rothstein said. ‚ÄúTwo, three years, tops. Yet ‚ÄòOh, oh, oh, Ozempic‚Äô continues to endure. You can do all the market research in the world, and never end up with something like this.‚Äù

Audio produced by Sarah Diamond.

title: Archaeologists Found the Tomb of an Actual Roman Soldier From Year Zero
description: A 2,000-year-old tomb discovered contained the remains of a Roman soldier identified as Flaccus after his nickname was seen on a terra sigillata bowl.
fullText:
Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll learn when you read this story:

A 2,000-year-old tomb discovered in Heerlen, Netherlands, contained the remains of a Roman soldier.

The site was first believed to be a cellar, but was determined to be a tomb after the discovery of an assortment of burial artifacts.

The soldier was identified as Flaccus after his nickname was seen on a terra sigillata bowl.

During an ADC ArcheoProjecten excavation near the town‚Äôs Raadhuisplein‚Äîtranslated as Town Hall Square‚Äîa team of archaeologists found what initially looked to be a cellar. But after further exploration, they found it was rife with bronze pieces, pottery, terra sigillata bowls and plates, and, most significantly, cremated remains‚Äînot exactly something you store in a cellar.

They realized they had stumbled upon an ancient tomb, and it didn‚Äôt take long to figure out whose.

The clay bowls held a key clue, as the abbreviation ‚ÄúFLAC‚Äù was engraved onto their sides, according to a statement from the town of Heerlen. The abbreviation serves as a nickname for Flaccus. Along with the bowl, the archaeologists found a personal bronze skin scraper and four different plates. The pottery, which comes from Italy, confirmed that Flaccus was a Roman soldier. ‚ÄúIt is a unique find because it is not only the oldest Roman grave in Heerlen, but also because no name was known there before,‚Äù the statement reads.

The find was dated to the year 0 and is the ‚Äúmost unique evidence of Roman habitation at this location.‚Äù Researchers had not previously found a Roman grave for this period accompanied by a name in the region.

The tomb and its personal artifacts are some of the first true pieces of evidence of an early Roman presence in the area. The settlement, likely the area‚Äôs first from the Roman expansion, was known as Coriovallum, and the deceased Flaccus is now the oldest known name of an individual in the city‚Äôs history.

The Raadhuisplein, located near the historical roads Via Belgica and Via Traina, was likely also an important location in the middle of Coriovallum, which became Heerlen centuries later. It served as a connection between Germany and France, a crossroads that contained a Roman military presence. It later grew into a more civilian-focused town and public baths built between 50 and 70 A.D., discovered in Heerlen in 1940, are still the largest visible Roman ruins in the Netherlands, according to Archaeology Magazine.

The artifacts from the tomb will eventually go on display at the Roman Museum of Heerlen.

‚ÄúEvidence was found of Roman habitation in the time of Emperor Augusts,‚Äù said Jordy Clemens, Heerlen‚Äôs councilmember for culture and heritage, according to Archaeology Magazine. ‚ÄúA unique discovery that not only teaches us more about our past, but also shows how unique the story of Roman Heerlen is for the Netherlands.‚Äù

title: Ignoring AI bubble fears, investors bet Nvidia and Google will fuel Taiwan stocks to record
description: Taiwan's tech-heavy stocks show few signs of slowing a rally even as AI bubble worries cast a shadow over global markets, underscoring home-grown confidence in the structural advantages in AI that foreign investors may have overlooked.  Taiwan's benchmark index is poised to breach ‚Äãa record 30,000 points in 2026, investors say, extending a three-year surge that has seen the stock market nearly double as the island rides a wave of demand ‚Äåfor chips that power artificial intelligence.  While foreign money worries about stretched AI valuations, Taiwanese investors have enthusiastically ploughed into the market.
fullText:
TAIPEI/SINGAPORE, Dec 12 (Reuters) - Taiwan's tech-heavy stocks show few signs of slowing a rally even as AI bubble worries cast a shadow over global markets, underscoring home-grown confidence in the structural advantages in AI that foreign investors may have overlooked.

Taiwan's benchmark index is poised to breach ‚Äãa record 30,000 points in 2026, investors say, extending a three-year surge that has seen the stock market nearly double as the island rides a wave of demand ‚Äåfor chips that power artificial intelligence.

While foreign money worries about stretched AI valuations, Taiwanese investors have enthusiastically ploughed into the market.

Analysts say domestic investors are betting on Taiwan's unique position as the lynchpin of an AI supply chain, where ‚Äåeven increasing competition in the sector would only benefit Taiwanese firms, including TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker.

One major focus of anxiety around AI comes from uncertainty about Nvidia's ability to sustain its market dominance, with Google's tensor processing units (TPUs) emerging as a potentially more cost-effective alternative to Nvidia's graphics processing units (GPUs).

But it's a win-win scenario for Taiwan because the island is essential to supply chains of both the GPU and TPU, the building blocks of AI computing power.

"Taiwan is a major beneficiary of the AI market," said Piter Yang, a fund manager of Fuh Hwa Securities Investment Trust Co, citing the ‚Å†advantage of Taiwan being the world's semiconductor hub.

And for now, as ‚Äåa promising future fuels optimism, Taiwan markets and local investors seem relatively unfazed by the AI bubble fears, just as they remain calm in the face of rising geopolitical tensions with Beijing that have often spooked foreign investors.

Gains in Taiwan's market have also been underpinned ‚Äçby earnings growth, leaving it with a reasonably steady price-to-earnings ratio of 21, below that of the Nasdaq and the Nikkei, meaning the rally has not made stocks more expensive.

"We are not worried about an AI bubble," said Li Fang-kuo, chairman of the securities investment arm of food conglomerate Uni-President. "We are comfortable with where the valuations stand."

Li pointed out that several of the magnificent seven companies in the U.S. have gross ‚Äãmargins of as much as 70% or higher. "So it's not comparable to the dot-com bubble, when companies were not generating meaningful earnings."

title: Tesla's latest launch isn't a car ‚Äî it's a $350 pickleball paddle ‚Äî and it's not even electric
description: Tesla has partnered with Selkirk to launch a $350 pickleball paddle "optimized for high performance play."
fullText:
From Elon Musk ‚Äî the guy who brought the world a branded flamethrower ‚Äî it somehow tracks that Tesla is now making pickleball paddles.

The EV company launched its latest lifestyle product on Friday: a $350 pickleball paddle created in partnership with Selkirk, a sports equipment company.

The paddle, made of carbon fiber with a foam core, was "optimized for high-performance play," according to the product page.

"This wasn't simply a branding exercise. It was a true engineering collaboration," Selkirk's co-owner and director of research and development, Tom Barnes, said in a statement about the release. "Tesla's design group and our R&D team spent more than a year trading data, refining geometry, and stress-testing prototypes."

A Selkirk spokesperson told Business Insider that the paddle's creation was first conceptualized after a conversation at the 2023 USA Pickleball National Championships between Barnes and members of Tesla's engineering team.

After Barnes delivered a custom batch of Tesla-themed paddles to the EV-maker's staff, Selkirk leaders visited the Tesla factory in Fremont, California. While there, they connected with Javier Verdura, Tesla's global director of product design, who is an avid pickleball player, and began the design process.

Prototypes were sent to Tesla for aerodynamics testing before the design was finalized.

The limited-run batch of the paddle sold out on Tesla's website in under three hours after its launch, a Selkirk spokesperson told Business Insider. Plans for a restock remain unclear.

While the pickleball paddle is Tesla's first foray into traditional, non-electrified sports equipment, the automaker does offer a line of apparel and home products, like drinkware ($30+), backpacks ($185+), and salt and pepper shakers ($65).

Musk's other business ventures have also leaned into collectible merchandise, such as the¬†Boring Company's flamethrower,¬†which went viral in 2018.

Tesla's lifestyle products are not listed as a separate line item in their financial reports, and there is no publicly available evidence to suggest that they¬†have a significant impact on¬†the company's finances. Tesla stock closed up more than 2% on Friday, but sank slightly in after-hours trading.

Pickleball, which combines elements of tennis, badminton, and ping-pong, has experienced explosive growth in popularity in recent years. The 2024 Pickleball Single Sport Report, released by the Sports and Fitness Industry Association, found that participation has increased by 45.8% since 2023 ‚Äî¬†representing 311% growth over the past three years.

In that time, pickleball has transformed from a suburban hobby for the 55+ crowd into a popular activity and networking opportunity among Silicon Valley professionals.

Entry-level equipment for the sport doesn't require a significant investment, with a basic paddle and ball running less than $50. However, since pickleball has gained traction among tech personalities like Bill Gates and celebrities like Leonardo DiCaprio, higher-end products have crept into the market.

Some Selkirk models run upward of $150, while others, like the Aero Blade 1.19, cost $299 and up. The Aero Blade features a carbon fiber frame with a foam core, similar to that of the Tesla version.

The debut of the Tesla pickleball paddle elicited split reactions on social media, with some fans of the brand celebrating its release as a clever gift opportunity ahead of the holiday season. Others were quick to criticize the price point and Selkirk's strategy to partner with Tesla, rather than a well-known pickleball player or influencer.

"Selkirks out here like 'We are going to let every signed pro walk, and then collab with the worlds biggest brands that have nothing to do with pickleball,'" Jimmy Miller, a pickleball player and host of the '"King of the Court" podcast, wrote in a post on X.

"Bold strategy. Curious if it pays off," he added. "Tesla fans will probably sell that paddle out. Who is next? Apple? Maybe they can do a Nvidia collab that comes with shares!"

title: Commander in charge of US military operations in the Caribbean retires after clashes with Hegseth over boat strikes
description: Adm. Alvin Holsey, the commander of US Southern Command who reportedly clashed with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over the legality of the US military strikes in the Caribbean, officially retired on Friday in a ceremony in Floria where he handed the reigns of the command to his deputy.
fullText:
Adm. Alvin Holsey, the commander of US Southern Command who reportedly clashed with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over the legality of US military strikes in the Caribbean, officially retired on Friday in a ceremony in Florida where he handed the reins of the command to his deputy.

Holsey thanked his wife, his sons ‚Äî one of whom is a currently deployed Naval aviator ‚Äî and others who attended the event.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm reminded that in life, we don‚Äôt remember days, we remember moments. Those we lead don‚Äôt follow titles, they follow courage, and they remember the moments and how you made them feel,‚Äù Holsey said. ‚ÄúThey remember those who listen and treated them with dignity and respect.‚Äù

Holsey will be replaced by Air Force Lt. Gen. Evan Pettus, who has been serving as his deputy at Southern Command since Holsey was elevated to the role last year.

Southern Command is responsible for managing US military operations in most of Latin America and the Caribbean Sea.

Holsey‚Äôs retirement was announced in October by Hegseth, less than a year into Holsey‚Äôs command and just days after the US conducted its fifth attack on an alleged drug trafficking boat off the coast of Venezuela. Hegseth and Holsey had disagreements over US operations in the region, two sources familiar with the matter previously told CNN.

Hegseth felt Holsey was not moving aggressively enough to combat drug traffickers in the Southern Command area of operations, CNN has reported, while Southern Command officials were concerned about the legality of the strikes.

Those issues came to a head in an October 6 meeting at the Pentagon between Holsey, Hegseth, and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Dan Caine. One of the sources familiar with the situation said Holsey offered to leave his post during that meeting, CNN has reported, but the offer was tabled.

The legality of the US strikes against alleged drug boats has come under increased scrutiny in recent weeks as lawmakers have demanded answers about a follow-on strike carried out in September that killed two survivors of an initial attack.

Caine, who presided over Friday‚Äôs ceremony, called Holsey a ‚Äúquiet professional‚Äù and ‚Äúan extraordinary human who‚Äôs always led with your heart, your head, and gone all-in every single day of your service.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve made an incredible difference to our joint force. You made an incredible difference here in this headquarters. You make an incredible difference to this nation‚Ä¶we will always be grateful for the gift of a great example for you and your family‚Äôs service and sacrifice, and for the way that you‚Äôve approached the professional wisdom of leadership and service,‚Äù Cain said. ‚ÄúThe impact that you‚Äôve had will last for a long, long time.‚Äù

Holsey‚Äôs successor, Pettus, is an Air Force Academy graduate and a pilot of the F-15e and A-10 with more than 2,700 flight hours, according to his official biography. Prior to joining Southern Command, Pettus led the 12th Air Force (Air Forces Southern) stationed out of Davis-Monthan Air Force Base, Arizona. Air Forces Southern provides ‚Äúair, space and cyberspace capabilities throughout Latin America and the Caribbean,‚Äù Pettus‚Äô bio says.

Pettus has been at Southern Command working as Holsey‚Äôs deputy during the alleged drug boat strike campaign that started in September at a time that the US has also been massing personnel and assets in the region and conducting training missions off the coast of Venezuela, even reopening a military base in Puerto Rico that had been closed for decades.

CNN has reported that a significant percentage of all deployed US Naval assets are now in the theater, including the Iwo Jima Amphibious Ready Group, the Gerald R. Ford Carrier Strike Group, and the 22nd Marine Expeditionary Unit. Those groups amount to roughly 15,000 US troops, multiple guided-missile destroyers, an attack submarine, a special operations ship, and various fighter aircraft.

The relinquishment of Holsey‚Äôs command also comes just days after the US seized an oil tanker off the coast of Venezuela; President Donald Trump said only that the vessel was seized for ‚Äúvery good reason,‚Äù in comments to reporters Wednesday. Attorney General Pam Bondi said in a social media post announcing the seizure that the tanker had been sanctioned by the US for years ‚Äúdue to its involvement in an illicit oil shipping network supporting foreign terrorist organizations.‚Äù

This story has been updated with additional details.

title: Doctors Say COVID Symptoms Are Changing‚ÄîHere‚Äôs What to Watch for With the New Variant
description: The symptoms of COVID-19 have changed over time. Here, infectious disease doctors share what many people are experiencing with the latest variant.
fullText:
The Stratus variant is fueling COVID-19 cases around the country.

Symptoms of the virus look slightly different right now.

Here, doctors share what to look out for and how to protect yourself from the latest variant.

A newer COVID variant called XFG is currently fueling cases of the virus across the country. Nicknamed ‚ÄúStratus,‚Äù this variant first took hold over the summer and now makes up nearly 70% of COVID-19 cases in the country. As the virus evolves, some signs you‚Äôre sick might too. So, what are COVID-19 symptoms in 2025?

While some liken it to the common cold, COVID-19 is still a lethal disease, and certain groups are still at a higher risk of a more severe form of the virus. But many people are experiencing an uncomfortable illness with symptoms that are slightly different from what having COVID-19 used to feel like.

Infectious disease doctors stress that every person‚Äôs experience with the virus is different. ‚ÄúSo many infections now are milder, but there are still people being hospitalized with COVID,‚Äù says William Schaffner, M.D., an infectious disease specialist and professor at the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine.

Meet the experts: Thomas Russo, M.D., professor and chief of infectious disease at the University at Buffalo in New York; William Schaffner, M.D., an infectious disease specialist and professor at the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine

Even if you‚Äôre not in a high-risk group for serious complications from COVID-19, ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt count on avoiding severe illness,‚Äù says Thomas Russo, M.D., professor and chief of infectious disease at the University at Buffalo in New York.

So, what are the biggest COVID symptoms right now? Here‚Äôs what you should know.

Again, everyone‚Äôs experience with COVID-19 is slightly different. ‚ÄúIt depends on a combination of how much virus you‚Äôre exposed to, what your underlying state of immunity is, and the underlying host‚Äîare you a younger, healthier host, an older host, or have underlying health conditions?‚Äù Dr. Russo says.

But doctors agree that there are a few COVID-19 symptoms that many people are experiencing:

This constellation of symptoms can make COVID-19 feel like a bad cold, if you‚Äôre lucky enough to get a mild case.

But it‚Äôs still possible to experience the other legacy symptoms of COVID-19, which may include:

Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing

It‚Äôs likely due to a few factors, including the different dominant variant and built-up immunity to the virus (from vaccination and previous infection), Dr. Russo says.

It‚Äôs also just the nature of the virus, according to Dr. Schaffner. ‚ÄúCOVID is a respiratory virus, and all of these viruses can produce similar symptoms involving the nose, throat, and chest,‚Äù he says.

Again, that doesn‚Äôt mean that this is what COVID-19 will look like for you‚Äîit‚Äôs just what many people are experiencing right now. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm thrilled that many people are experiencing mild symptoms, but you can‚Äôt count on that, particularly if you haven‚Äôt gotten your vaccine or boosters, and haven‚Äôt recently been infected,‚Äù Dr. Russo says. ‚ÄúThe subsequent consequences of COVID, in terms of long COVID, is much more significant than it is for influenza.‚Äù

According to wastewater data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), COVID-19 cases are currently high in these states:

There are plenty of other states with moderate levels of the virus, per CDC data.

The amount of time you‚Äôre contagious with COVID-19 can vary, but the virus tends to follow a certain pattern in terms of being able to infect others. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre contagious for the day before you get sick and then most contagious for the next two to three days,‚Äù Dr. Schaffner says. ‚ÄúIt tapers off after that, but it‚Äôs not like a light switch.‚Äù

If you‚Äôve been vaccinated, the amount of time that you‚Äôre contagious will be less than if you‚Äôre unvaccinated, Dr. Russo says. Overall, Dr. Russo says it‚Äôs safe to assume that you‚Äôre not likely to infect anyone 10 days after you first got sick. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a safe rule of thumb,‚Äù he says.

If you‚Äôre planning to be around people who are vulnerable to getting seriously ill before then, like small children, older adults, and people with underlying health conditions, Dr. Russo recommends wearing a mask.

No shocker here‚Äîdoctors recommend getting your updated COVID-19 vaccine, if you haven‚Äôt already. ‚ÄúThink about getting out your mask and think twice about those holiday gatherings, especially if you‚Äôre high-risk,‚Äù Dr. Schaffner says. And, of course, do your best to stay away from people who are obviously sick.

While many people have stopped testing themselves for COVID-19, it‚Äôs still worth taking an at-home COVID test if you‚Äôll be around vulnerable people‚Äîor just don‚Äôt want to spread what you‚Äôve got to anyone.

title: Manchester City look to have locked in on their preferred right-back to add to Pep Guardiola‚Äôs squad
description: Looking ahead to the January and summer transfer windows, there look to be two main positions that Manchester City will look to strengthen. It would not be a surprise to see City move for another wing...
fullText:
Looking ahead to the January and summer transfer windows, there look to be two main positions that Manchester City will look to strengthen. It would not be a surprise to see City move for another winger or attacking player in January. Omar Marmoush will be unavailable for an extended period of time due to the African Cup of Nations. City could benefit from signing another attacking player next month. It would also seem that Pep Guardiola‚Äôs squad would benefit from signing a right-back. That move appears to be one that will likely take place in the summer and there is one player who is emerging as City‚Äôs main target for the right-back role.

Two new reports have emerged that state that Manchester City could move for Tino Livramento next summer. The first comes from Craig Hope for the Daily Mail. Hope reports that Tino Livramento is set to delay any decision on signing a contract extension with Newcastle United until near the end of this season. Furthermore, Hope reports that Livramento‚Äôs long-term future is uncertain. Hope further reports that Manchester City have a strong interest in signing the England international. Lastly, it is also reported that if Newcastle United qualify for next season‚Äôs UEFA Champions League, Tino Livramento could sign a contract extension with Newcastle. Newcastle United are determined to keep Livramento at the club as per Craig Hope‚Äôs report.

Jordan Campbell has reported for The Athletic that Manchester City decided not to pursue a move for Tino Livramento last summer as they deemed a move for the England international as out of reach. Furthermore, Campbell reports that Tino Livramento is highly appreciated as a player at City. Campbell also reports that City could have to pay near enough to ¬£100 million to sign Tino Livramento from Newcastle United if he doesn‚Äôt sign a contract extension with Eddie Howe‚Äôs side.

All indications are that Manchester City have identified Tino Livramento as the primary transfer target to come in at right-back. Matheus Nunes has done a superb job playing in the position this season. Nunes‚Äô game has improved and there is no reason why he cannot remain as Manchester City‚Äôs first-choice right-back for this season. Abdukodir Khusanov can step in for Nunes when required. It would be almost impossible for City to sign Tino Livramento in January so the England international would look to be a summer target for City.

Based on Craig Hope and Jordan Campbell‚Äôs reports it seems to now be a matter of when City will make their move to sign Tino Livramento from Newcastle, not if they will make that particular move. There is now too much noise to suggest otherwise. Livramento would almost be the ideal signing for City. He is a homegrown player blessed with tremendous technical ability and he is a tremendous defender at either left or right-back. He is also the ideal age to arrive at City as an established player with his best years ahead of him. Livramento ticks every box required of a potential Manchester City signing.

As of right now, unless Livramento extends his contract with Newcastle, it seems that City will move to sign Tino Livramento. It will likely be a move that Manchester City will pursue next summer. Whether or not that move will be successful remains to be seen. But it would appear that City have identified their top target to sign for the right-back position.

title: Georgia offers Michigan State 4-star WR commit Samson Gash
description: Detroit Catholic Central four-star wide receiver Samson Gash is one of the few unsigned blue-chippers left in the 2026 cycle. The 6-foot pass-catcher has been committed to Michigan State since June 24, but he decided not to sign earlier this month as the Spartans had a change at head coach and elsewhere on the staff. [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Detroit Catholic Central four-star wide receiver Samson Gash is one of the few unsigned blue-chippers left in the 2026 cycle.

The 6-foot pass-catcher has been committed to Michigan State since June 24, but he decided not to sign earlier this month as the Spartans had a change at head coach and elsewhere on the staff. The in-state program still holds his commitment, but other programs are in the mix, too.

Another notable offer came through for Gash on Friday. He took to social media to announce an offer from James Coley and the Georgia Bulldogs:

Blessed to receive an offer from Georgia!!

@CoachColey@KirbySmartUGA@DHill39@AllenTrieu@GregSmithRivals@SWiltfong_@adamgorneypic.twitter.com/cIFyIumAHB

WR (@GashSamson) December 13, 2025

With UGA in the mix, it could throw another wrinkle in the recruitment of Gash, which has taken multiple turns this fall. Before the coaching change in East Lansing, Michigan State was already trying to fend off Alabama.

The Crimson Tide were in pursuit of Gash this fall and a flip looked to be probable, but the SEC program took its foot off the gas. After the firing of Michigan State head coach Jonathan Smith, Gash began to draw interest from West Virginia.

At the end of the National Signing Period last week, it looked the Mountaineers were in the driver‚Äôs seat. Earlier this week, though, Penn State and new head coach Matt Campbell jumped in with an offer. Gash‚Äôs father, Sam Gash, played for the Nittany Lions.

‚ÄúThis offer means a lot to me. It‚Äôs been a long time coming,‚Äù Gash told BWI. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been up there a few times and I know the program is in great hands with this new Iowa State staff that I like and trust a lot after they were recruiting me a little bit at Iowa State.‚Äù

Georgia will now look to make its presence felt for Gash, who won‚Äôt put pen to paper until February. The Bulldogs lost four-star WR Brady Marchese during the signing period as he flipped to Michigan. They did still sign a pair of four-star wideouts last week in Craig Dandridge and Ryan Mosley.

Michigan State, now led by Pat Fitzgerald, still signed 19 prospects last week. It would love to keep Gash in the mix, too, but it won‚Äôt be easy.

‚ÄúIt feels really good knowing MSU is in good hands and is a safe option for me and great hire,‚Äù Gash told Rivals‚Äô Greg Smith about the Fitzgerald hire.

Gash is the No. 292 overall prospect and No. 46 WR in the 2026 cycle, according to the¬†Rivals Industry Ranking, a weighted average that utilizes all major recruiting media companies. He‚Äôs also the No. 6 recruit in Michigan.

fullText:
Melissa (TX) vs. South Oak Cliff (TX): Live updates, score of Texas UIL 5A Division II Friday night semifinal contest in Dallas originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Friday night lights will be at the venerable Cotton Bowl in Dallas, the original home of the Dallas Cowboys.

The winner of the Texas University Interscholastic League 5A Division II semifinal between Melissa and South Oak Cliff will get to play for a state title next week at the Cowboys‚Äô current home, Arlington‚Äôs AT&T Stadium.

LIVE STREAM:Watch Melissa vs. South Oak Cliff live on the NFHS Network ()

After missing a postseason berth last season, Melissa has come into this season with a vengeance. The Cardinals come into Friday‚Äôs semifinal round at 11-2, and were able to get past Argyle, 20-19, in last week‚Äôs regional final.

South Oak Cliff (13-1) is seeking to go to the state championship game for the fifth straight year. The Golden Bears won back-to-back 5A DII titles in 2021-22, but lost in the championship games each of the past two seasons.

There is also a recent playoff history between the two schools. SOC and Melissa played in the area round two years ago, with the Golden Bears pulling away in the second half for an eventual 38-30 win. They also beat Melissa in the 2022 regional final round, 30-16, on the road to winning their second straight 5A DII title.

Friday‚Äôs semifinal winner plays the winner of the other semifinal, between defending champion Richmond Randle and Boerne, which is also taking place Friday in San Antonio, at next week‚Äôs UIL State in Arlington.

title: Rangers sign $14.5 million free agent catcher to replace Jonah Heim
description: Texas has its new backstop.
fullText:
Rangers sign $14.5 million free agent catcher to replace Jonah Heim originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Texas Rangers made the choice earlier in the offseason to cut Jonah Heim loose.

It meant that the Rangers would have to seek out a new starting catcher in free agency, and now they've got their man.

Jansen has signed a two-year deal for $14.5 million, according to ESPN's Jeff Passan.

Jansen is a 30-year old catcher originally from Appleton, Wisconsin. The Blue Jays took him in the 16th round of the 2013 MLB Draft out of high school.

The righty hitter gained pretty solid acclaim as a prospect in the Toronto system and made his MLB debut in 2018. He played his first six-and-a-half seasons with the Blue Jays.

MORE:¬†Christian Yelich shows his puppy a proper appreciation of Tavon Austin

In his Toronto tenure, Jansen had a .733 OPS, hitting 71 home runs in 471 games.

He then spent half a season with the Boston Red Sox to end 2024.

In 2025, Jansen split the year between the Tampa Bay Rays and Milwaukee Brewers.

Jansen had an OPS of .703 with the Rays, then was pretty hot in limited duty with the Brewers, putting up a .779 OPS.

Now, Jansen gets to play for yet another team.

The Rangers now have their catcher depth chart set. They have Kyle Higashioka returning for the second season of his two-year contract signed last winter.

Jansen would likely be the favorite to win the job, but the Rangers can feel good that they have two reliable veterans on hand.

title: Rangers sign Edwin Diaz's All-Star brother to free agent contract
description: Texas is hoping for a rebound here.
fullText:
Rangers sign Edwin Diaz's All-Star brother to free agent contract originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Texas Rangers have signed a former All Star who is the brother of one of this offseason's big free agent moves.

No, they didn't get Edwin Diaz. They got his brother Alexis in a deal reporter by ESPN's Jeff Passan on Friday night.

Alexis is a 29-year old righty who as recently as 2023 was an All-Star closer for the Cincinnati Reds.

He made his MLB debut in 2022 and had a 1.84 ERA in 59 games.

The next season, he saved 37 games, and in 2024, he saved 28 and still had a 3.99 ERA.

MORE:¬†Christian Yelich shows his puppy a proper appreciation of Tavon Austin

The rails fell off quickly in 2025.

Alexis Diaz had a 12.00 ERA in six outings with the Reds before they let him go.

The Dodgers pick him up next, and he had a 5.00 ERA in nine games there before they too let him go.

The Atlanta Braves gave Diaz a quick chance down the stretch, and he had a 10.13 ERA in three outings.

It seems like multiple teams have viewed Alexis Diaz as a worthy reclamation project. His stuff was really good as recently as a couple seasons ago.

Relievers are volatile, and some never get back to their form.

But if the Rangers get Alexis Diaz back to his 2022-23 level, it'll be a huge steal to get him now in free agency.

title: Northwestern vs. Raines: live score, updates, highlights from Florida's FHSAA Class 3A championship
description: The No. 22 Northwestern Bulls will face the Raines Vikings Friday night in Florida's FHSAA Class 3A state championship game
fullText:
Northwestern vs. Raines: live score, updates, highlights from Florida's FHSAA Class 3A championship originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

MIAMI, Florida, Dec. 12 ‚Äî¬†The¬†Northwestern [Miami, FL] Bulls¬†roll into Florida's FHSAA Class 3A title Friday evening with a 23-game win streak and an undefeated 13-0 record as they look to defend their 2024 state championship at Florida International University's Pitbull Stadium.

Their opponent will look very familiar as they'll face the same Raines [Jacksonville, FL] Vikings' squad they beat, 41-0, in last year's title tilt. Raines also sports a 13-0 record headed into the contest.

Northwestern will be seeking its eight state championship in football while Raines is in the hunt for its fourth football state championship trophy.

Game time is set for 7:30 p.m. EST local.

WATCH ON THE NFHS NETWORK:No. 22 Northwestern [Miami, FL] Bulls vs. Raines [Jacksonville, FL] Vikings

This Raines defense! I've been talking about them all night here, and they get an interception with a big return when Northwestern goes for it on fourth down. After trailing by nine, the Vikings are, amazingly, in business.

With 7:12 to play, Raines finally has some points from the offense, tacking on a field goal. It's important. It gets this back to a one-score game, and a touchdown and PAT could possibly win it.

This was never going to be easy for Raines, and it just got a lot harder as the Vikings' defense finally gives up its first touchdown. Northwestern back firmly in control in a two-score game now.

Well, Raines has finally scored against Northwestern, but it's the only 7 points they have in seven quarters against this Northwestern team the past two years. But, the difference this year is their defense is keeping this thing close. And that defense might have to go and win this thing for them.

Northwestern shakes off the interception and drives down into position for another field goal. But these are still small victories for the Vikings. They're giving their offense every opportunity to go win this game.

Well, the defense for Raines has been keeping them in this game, and now they've given the Vikings the lead on a long interception return. This is a crazy swing, and in seven quarters of play against Northwestern, this is the first points Raines has managed. But this is no anomaly; this is the Viking's 12th defensive touchdown this year.

Northwestern adds another field goal, but Raines' defense is playing tough tonight. They're giving the offense a chance if it can ever get on track.

And the third quarter is just getting under way!

This is looking a lot better than last year, but one important number is the same so far ‚Äì that goose egg on the Vikings' side of the scoreboard. They lost last year's game 41-0, and through two quarters tonight, the offense still hasn't cracked the code against this stout Bulls' defense.

Raines was finally driving deep in Northwestern's territory, helped along by a pass interference penalty. But then they throw an interception near the 5 yard line with 39 seconds to play in the first half.

Khavon Gipson with a clutch interception for Northwestern. Raines was driving. pic.twitter.com/WKTZkhHnnN

‚Äî Adam Lichtenstein (@ABLichtenstein) December 13, 2025

Northwestern was about to score when the running back took a hard lick near the goal line. The ball rolled into the end zone where Raines recovered to take over. The Vikings' defense is bending but not breaking. But they need some help from the offense late in the second quarter.

Raines was pinned deep in its own territory after the turnover on downs. They were forced to punt from their end zone, but Northwestern mishandles the punt, and Raines pounces on it. Northwestern would have had great field position around the Vikings' 30, but instead, the Vikings keep their drive alive.

Northwestern takes their second drive inside the Raines' 5. On fourth and goal, they go for the first down, but the Vikings' defense forces the turnover on downs!

Northwestern puts together a solid drive, but Raines' defense stands tall in the shadow of their own end zone to force a field goal.

Field goal! @mnw_fb scores first. Alex Lima field goal from 24. Good stand inside 10 by Raines.

Miami Northwestern 3, Raines 0, 6:19 1st. pic.twitter.com/Yy2cYhzKfG

‚Äî Clayton Freeman (@CFreemanJAX) December 13, 2025

The game is under way in Miami, Florida!

Start time: 7:30 p.m. EST local

The game between Northwestern and Raines is being played at Florida International University's Pitbull Stadium.

WATCH ON THE NFHS NETWORK:No. 22 Northwestern [Miami, FL] Bulls vs. Raines [Jacksonville, FL] Vikings
